author: gqlshare
title: Mark Meadows, Trump’s chief of staff, indicted in Arizona election interference case
text:
Danielle Battaglia | (TNS) McClatchy Washington Bureau
WASHINGTON — An Arizona grand jury has indicted Mark Meadows, former President Donald Trump’s chief of staff and a former congressman, over his involvement in efforts to overturn the 2020 election using a fake slate of electors from the state.
He is among 18 people charged, though his name does not appear in the indictment. Trump is not charged.
Prosecutors gave enough details in the indictment , dated Tuesday and posted on social media by a Politico reporter, to reveal Meadows as one of the defendants whose names are redacted.
Trump is consistently referred to in the indictment as “Unindicted Coconspirator 1.” A description of one of the defendants with redacted names describes him as that co-conspirator’s chief of staff.
Charges for the group include conspiracy, fraudulent schemes and artifices, fraudulent schemes and practices and forgery.
Since Meadows’ name is redacted, the full scope of the allegations against him is not immediately clear.
This is the second time Meadows, formerly a congressman from North Carolina, has been indicted for allegations that he tried to overturn the 2020 election. The other case is in Georgia, where he’s facing two charges of racketeering and solicitation of violation of oath of a public officer, according to that indictment.
Meadows has defended himself , saying the actions he is accused of taking were within the purview of his job as a chief of staff.
The fake electors The latest indictment details how those close to Trump worked with a fake group of electors from Arizona to try to overthrow the election results, where Biden won by more than 10,000 votes.
“In Arizona, and the United States, the people elected Joseph Biden as President on November 3, 2020,” the indictment states. “Unwilling to accept this fact, Defendants and unindicted coconspirators schemed to prevent the lawful transfer of the presidency to keep Unindicted Coconspirator 1 in office against the will of Arizona’s voters.”
The indictment further states that the scheme would have deprived Arizonans of their right to vote and have their votes counted.
Among those indicted are 11 people described as the Arizona Fake Electors. They’re accused of declaring Trump and former Vice President Mike Pence as the winners of the 2020 election in Arizona, despite voter intent.
The other seven people indicted include Meadows, Trump’s director of Election Day operations and five attorneys, one of whom was a campaign aide. Their names have been redacted from the indictment, though The Washington Post is identifying them as Rudy Giuliani, Jenna Ellis, John Eastman, Christina Bob, Trump’s campaign adviser Boris Epshteyn and former campaign aide Mike Roman.
Meadows is specifically accused of working “with members of the Trump campaign to coordinate and implement the false Republican electors’ votes in Arizona and six other states.” It further accuses him of being involved in many efforts to keep Trump in power, despite losing the election.
Before working in the Trump administration, Meadows represented North Carolina’s 11th Congressional District, in the state’s farthest southwestern counties. He was succeeded by former Rep. Madison Cawthorn, who lost his reelection in 2022 to Rep. Chuck Edwards.
Trump faces four criminal indictments in other cases, including accusations of interference in the 2020 election and an alleged hush money scheme in a case on trial now.

author: redaccion@heraldo.es (Gonzalo de la Figuera)
title: ¿Cómo estaba el honky tonk? ¡Abarrotao!
text: ¿Cómo estaba el honky tonk? ¡Abarrotao! Al parecer las celebraciones familiares del Día de Reyes dejaron a mucha gente con ganas de cambiar el chip y echarse a la calle, pues el Rock & Blues Café estaba abarrotado para asistir a la actuación del californiano Mitch Polzak, quien en condiciones normales (y sobre todo con entrada de pago) apenas habría reunido a una tercera parte del público que allí se congregó. Polzak, un tipo muy alto, de rostro anguloso y aspecto de secundario de una peli de Lynch o Tarantino, convirtió la sala en un bullicioso honky tonk de carretera del sur de Estados Unidos con un variado repertorio que abarcaba todas las ramas del frondoso árbol de la música de raíces americanas. Notable cantante y guitarrista muy competente (en esta ocasión prescindió del banjo, del que también es un consumado intérprete), el larguirucho Mitch se paseó con naturalidad y mucho oficio por amplios territorios sonoros que van del country al rockabilly, del bluegrass al surf, del rock and roll primigenio al blues, entre otras cosas. Por ahí van asomando los espíritus de Waylon Jennings y Merle Haggard, de Jerry Lee Lewis y Chuck Berry, de Link Wray y Dick Dale. El soporte rítmico lo pone su banda española, The Kaw-ligas, integrada por Jesús López (batería) y José Miguel Jarque (contrabajo). La primera parte de su extenso concierto resultó francamente entretenida y estimulante, alternando piezas de marcados aires campestres con andanadas de rockabilly frenético, incursiones en el rhythm and blues o ecos a la Creedence más pantanosa. Pero en la recta final le dio por atacar clásicos surferos (‘Misirlou’, por ejemplo) o una suerte de arrebato pseudo-aflamencado propio de quien quiere caer en gracia a la parroquia lugareña, y poco a poco el interés –al menos el nuestro- comenzó a decaer. Pero vaya, el público lo pasó en grande saboreando un roscón sonoro en el ‘honky tonk’ del Tubo. LA FICHA ‘Mitch Polzak & The Kaw-ligas’ *** Músicos: Mitch Polzak, voz y guitarra; José Miguel Jarque, contrabajo, Jesús López, batería. Sábado, 6 de enero de 2024. Rock & Blues Café, Zaragoza. Lleno. [Regístrate gratis](https://www.heraldo.es) [Iniciar sesión](https://www.heraldo.es)

author: Paul Cowley
title: Lacombe County council passes on agriculture review

author: Daily Excelsior
title: NC pays tribute to Begum Akbar Jehan on her death anniversary - Daily Excelsior
text: Excelsior Correspondent JAMMU, July 11: The Jammu and Kashmir National Conference today paid glowing tribute to Madr-e-Meharban Begum Akbar Jehan Abdullah on her 24th death anniversary during a programme held at party office here today. On the occasion, Ajay Sadhotra, additional general secretary and former minister, Rattan Lal Gupta, Provincial president and Sheikh Bashir Ahmed, Provincial secretary Jammu, Babu Rampaul Central Zone president and former minister along with party leaders and workers, paid glowing tribute to Begum Abdullah. Today’s programme was organized by Bimla Luthra, State vice president of the JKNC Women Wing and former MLA, to commemorate the death anniversary of Madr-e-Meharban. Earlier GH Malik organized Quran Khawani on this occasion. A two-minute silence was observed as a mark of respect to the memory of Madr-e-Meharban. Speaking on the occasion, Sadhotra criticized the current Government for its failure to empower women in Jammu and Kashmir. He accused the BJP Government at the Centre and the Union Territory Administration of providing nothing but lip service, leaving the women of J&K neglected and underserved. Rattan Lal Gupta, recalled the role of Madr-e-Meharban as a conscience-keeper of the party during the political struggle of Jammu and Kashmir, particularly after the arrest of Sheikh Mohammed Abdullah. He said Begum Abdullah led the National Conference at a very crucial juncture of the political evolution of Jammu and Kashmir when Late Abdullah was in prison. He emphasized that Madr-e-Meharban proved to be an affectionate mother, a dynamic leader, and a great human being who had a deep concern for the welfare and well-being of the people. He said Begum Abdullah will always remain an inspiration for the women of the state. Bimla Luthra recalled the contribution of Begum Abdullah to women’s emancipation and empowerment and said the best tribute to her would be to concentrate on improving the status of women and ensuring their dignity at all costs. Among others who were present include- Master Noor Hussain, Pardeep Bali, Ankush Abrol, Vijay Lochan, Abdul Gani Teli, Satwant Kour Dogra, Vijay Laxami Datta, Shamim Begum, Chander Mohan Sharma, Raghbir Singh Manhas, Sudagar Gupta, Rakesh Singh, Mohinder Singh, Ashok Kumar Attri, Vikram Puri and others.

author: Muhammad Jawad
title: Scotland's Leader Denounces Suella Braverman's Divisive Remarks on Islamists Leading the UK
text:
In an era where political discourse often tiptoes the line between boldness and controversy, Suella Braverman's recent comments have ignited a firestorm of criticism, with Scotland's First Minister, Humza Yousaf, leading the charge. Labeling Braverman 'the worst of politicians,' Yousaf's condemnation speaks volumes, reflecting the growing concern over the divisive nature of political rhetoric in the UK today.
Unpacking the Controversy
Braverman's contentious assertions, published in a
Daily Telegraph article, accused the Labour Party and the Speaker of the House of Commons, Lindsay Hoyle, of yielding to Islamist and extremist pressures. This was in context to a debated motion for a ceasefire in Gaza, a topic already fraught with political sensitivities. Her history of provocative statements, coupled with being sacked twice from the Cabinet—most recently for alleging police bias in protest handling—paints a picture of a politician unafraid to court controversy, albeit at significant risk to her political career.
The Backlash
The backlash was swift and severe. Critics argue that Braverman's remarks do more than just fan the flames of an already heated debate; they risk stoking racial and religious tensions at a time when unity is desperately needed. The response from political figures has been notably sharp, with Yvette Cooper and Rishi Sunak among those condemning her statements as baseless and inflammatory. The reference to
Cooper's criticism highlights a broader concern within the political community about the consequences of such divisive rhetoric.
A Divided Landscape
At its core, this controversy sheds light on deeper issues within UK politics. The stark division, particularly around topics of race, religion, and foreign policy, poses a significant challenge to political dialogue and collaboration. Braverman's comments, and the ensuing fallout, underscore the volatile nature of political discourse in the UK, where statements can quickly escalate into national, even international, discussions with far-reaching implications. The situation calls for a careful balancing act from politicians, where the need to address critical issues does not come at the expense of social cohesion and unity.
As the dust settles, the political landscape in the UK remains charged, a testament to the power of words in shaping public discourse. The controversy surrounding Braverman's comments is not an isolated incident but a reflection of the broader challenges facing politicians in navigating the complexities of modern political and social issues. The call from figures like Humza Yousaf for a more restrained and respectful political dialogue is a reminder of the responsibility borne by those in the public eye to foster a climate of understanding, rather than division.

author: John Russell
title: Gay Republicans swoon over Donald Trump for hosting a gay wedding at Mar-a-Lago
text:
Mar-a-Lago — the Palm Beach, Florida, resort and home of former President Donald Trump — recently hosted the same-sex wedding of an official from the Tennessee chapter of the Log Cabin Republicans (a gay conservative group) and his partner.
John Sullivan, the vice chairman and treasurer of the Log Cabin Republicans of Tennessee, and Dan Medora tied the knot at the opulent private club owned by the former president last Friday, according to anti-Trump political action committee
MeidasTouch Network,
Related:
[Trump promises to fight for gay Republicans days after Biden signs marriage equality bill]
Trump recently referred to LGBTQ+ people as “sickos” who “support the perverted sexualization of minor children.”
“An amazing time was had by all at John Sullivan and Dan Medora’s unforgettable wedding at Mar-a-Lago in Palm Beach, FL,” a post on the Log Cabin Republicans of Tennessee’s Facebook page reads. “A celebration of love and style that will be cherished forever. Thanks for the amazing weekend, fellas!”
Stay connected to your community
Connect with the issues and events that impact your community at home and beyond by
[subscribing to our daily newsletter].
On Instagram, Sullivan reportedly thanked Trump specifically for “giving us the green light to have our wedding at the beautiful Mar-a-Lago club.”
Sullivan’s Instagram account is now set to private, and it is unclear whether the former president personally approved the event. Though with mounting legal bills — more than a half-billion dollars
stemming from his many court cases — it seems unlikely that Trump would turn down a paycheck.
As MeidasTouch notes, Trump has been known to crash weddings at his Palm Beach resort, though he doesn’t appear to have attended Sullivan and Medora’s. On Friday afternoon, the former president was in South Carolina for a campaign rally ahead of the state’s Republican primary on Saturday.
While Trump shamelessly courted the LGBTQ+ vote during his 2016 presidential campaign, he repeatedly voiced his opposition to marriage equality, telling journalists in interviews, “
I think the institution of marriage should be between a man and a woman,” “ I’m opposed to gay marriage,” and “ I’m just for traditional marriage.” He also said that he would “ strongly consider” appointing Supreme Court justices who oppose marriage equality, and that Evangelicals “ can trust me on traditional marriage.”
That has not stopped the Log Cabin Republicans, which bills itself as “the nation’s largest Republican organization dedicated to representing LGBT conservatives and allies,” from supporting Trump. The organization previously held its annual
Spirit of Lincoln Gala honoring former First Lady Melania Trump at Mar-a-Lago in 2021. The former president was a no-show at that event as well. The group
The Log Cabin Republicans
have been compared to “Jews for Hitler.” The group has defended Florida’s “Don’t Say Gay” bill by comparing its opponents to pedophiles who have “wet dreams of gender fluid, indoctrinated, and groomed children.” The group’s President Charles Moran has written op-eds opposing transgender civil rights and also the Equality Act, legislation that includes LGBTQ+ nondiscrimination protections. An LCR ambassador said she wished society and conservatives were more homophobic. Trump did attend the group’s gala when it returned to Mar-a-Lago in 2022, telling the crowd that, “We are fighting for the gay community, and we are fighting and fighting hard.” He said this despite his many attacks on LGBTQ+ rights during his time in office.
While the 2022 Spirit of Lincoln Gala took place just days after President Joe Biden signed the historic “Respect for Marriage Act” — an act repealing the anti-LGBTQ+ “Defense of Marriage Act” and requiring the federal government and all U.S. states to recognize legal same-sex marriages — Trump made no mention of same-sex marriage at the event.
